importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The incident occurred on October 19, 2025, and was reported at 11:41 PM EDT, marking a significant aviation safety event in Hong Kong.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The cargo plane skidded off the runway at approximately 3:50 a.m. local time, which is critical for understanding the timeline of the incident and emergency response.

keyTakeAways: A cargo plane operated by ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport and crashed into the sea, killing two airport staff in a patrol vehicle.
The Boeing aircraft broke in two upon impact, with the tail section snapped off and significant damage to the front section below the cockpit.
The flight, numbered Emirates but wet-leased from ACT Airlines, had no distress signals during approach and was cleared for landing.
Four crew members were injured and sent to hospitals; no cargo was on board.
The airport suspended operations on the north runway until the aircraft is recovered, though two other runways remain operational and flights are not significantly disrupted.
Over 200 people, fire engines, and boats were involved in the emergency response.
This incident highlights rare but serious aviation safety risks, despite Hong Kong International Airport’s generally low accident rate in history.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A cargo plane operated by Turkish cargo carrier ACT Airlines, flying under an Emirates flight number, skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) early Monday, around 3:50 a.m. local time, and crashed into the sea, killing two airport staff in a security patrol vehicle. The Boeing aircraft broke in two upon impact, with significant damage to the front section. Despite no distress signals being reported, the aircraft was not in distress during approach. Four crew members were injured and taken to hospitals. The airport suspended operations on the north runway while emergency teams, including over 200 personnel and boats, responded. Historical context includes a 1999 crash at HKIA involving a China Airlines flight, which underscores the rarity of such incidents. This event highlights ongoing aviation safety concerns and the complexity of international flight operations involving wet-leasing arrangements.
title: Two killed as cargo plane skids off runway into the sea in Hong Kong
